Question

A very innocent monkey throws a fair die. The monkey will eat as many bananas as are shown on the die, from 1 to 5. But if the die shows '6', the monkey will eat 5 bananas and throw the die again. This may continue indefinitely. What is the expected number of bananas the monkey will eat?

Hint

The pattern repeats after the first throw

Answer

4

Solution

Method 1

The intuition is that either the die is thrown only once, or more than once. In case of only once, the expected value is 333. In case of more than once, the expected value is 555 + expected value of a new game. We need to find the expected value combining these two.

Let XXX be number of bananas eaten overall and YYY = number shown on the first dice.

E1=E[X∣only once]=E[X∣Y<6]=15(1+2+3+4+5)=3E_1 = E[X | \text{only once}] = E[X | Y < 6] = \dfrac{1}{5}(1+2+3+4+5) = 3E1​=E[X∣only once]=E[X∣Y<6]=51​(1+2+3+4+5)=3

E2=E[X∣more than once]=E[X∣Y=6]=5+E[X]E_2 = E[ X | \text{more than once}] = E[X | Y=6] = 5 + E[X]E2​=E[X∣more than once]=E[X∣Y=6]=5+E[X]

now, E[X]=56⋅E1+16⋅E2E[X] = \dfrac{5}{6}\cdot E_1 + \dfrac{1}{6} \cdot E_2E[X]=65​⋅E1​+61​⋅E2​

  ⟹  E[X]=56⋅3+16⋅(5+E[X])\implies E[X] = \dfrac{5}{6} \cdot 3 + \dfrac{1}{6} \cdot (5 + E[X])⟹E[X]=65​⋅3+61​⋅(5+E[X])

Solving this equation gives E[X]=4E[X] = 4E[X]=4

Mathematically, this is called the law of total probability, i.e, E[E[X∣Y]]=E[X]E[ E[X|Y] ] = E[X]E[E[X∣Y]]=E[X].

The denominator 5 is not intuitive when solving E1E_1E1​. For this reason, I have written the second method.

Method 2

Here, we will solve with basic algebra, without any special techniques.

Let XXX be the total number of banans eaten.

We know that E[X]=P(X=1)⋅1+P(X=2)⋅2+…E[X]= P(X=1)\cdot 1 + P(X=2) \cdot 2 + \ldotsE[X]=P(X=1)⋅1+P(X=2)⋅2+…

For the first 555 terms, the sum is simply 1/6⋅(1+2+3+4+5)=15/61/6 \cdot (1+2+3+4+5) = 15/61/6⋅(1+2+3+4+5)=15/6

666th term onwards, we can see a pattern:

P(X=6)⋅6+P(X=7)⋅7+…P(X=6) \cdot 6 + P(X=7) \cdot 7 + \ldotsP(X=6)⋅6+P(X=7)⋅7+…

Note that X≥6X\ge 6X≥6 occurs when the die is thrown again, i.e, P(X=i)=1/6⋅P(X=i−5)P(X=i) = 1/6 \cdot P(X=i - 5)P(X=i)=1/6⋅P(X=i−5) for i≥6i\ge 6i≥6.

Let's substitute these values in the above equation.

16[P(X=1)⋅6+P(X=2)⋅7+…] \dfrac{1}{6} [ P(X=1) \cdot 6 + P(X=2) \cdot 7 + \ldots ]61​[P(X=1)⋅6+P(X=2)⋅7+…]

Now, let's move the extra terms aside, to make it look more like E[X]E[X]E[X]

16[P(X=1)⋅1+P(X=2)⋅2+…]+16[P(X=1)⋅5+P(X=2)⋅5+…] \dfrac{1}{6} [ P(X=1) \cdot 1 + P(X=2) \cdot 2 + \ldots ] + \dfrac{1}{6} [P(X=1) \cdot 5 + P(X=2) \cdot 5 + \ldots]61​[P(X=1)⋅1+P(X=2)⋅2+…]+61​[P(X=1)⋅5+P(X=2)⋅5+…]

The left part is equal to 16E[X]\dfrac{1}{6} E[X]61​E[X], while the right part is 1/6⋅5[1/6 \cdot 5 [1/6⋅5[ probability of everything ]=5/6] = 5/6 ]=5/6

  ⟹  E[X]=156+16E[X]+56\implies E[X] = \dfrac{15}{6} + \dfrac{1}{6}E[X] + \dfrac{5}{6}⟹E[X]=615​+61​E[X]+65​

This simplifies to E[X]=4E[X] = 4E[X]=4

Method 3

Another method is to expand all the terms using linearity of expectation and then use GP sum formula.

Let XiX_iXi​ denote the number of bananas eaten on the iiith throw.

Thus, E[X]=E[∑i=1∞Xi]=∑i=1∞E[Xi]E[X] = E[\sum_{i=1}^{\infty} X_i] = \sum_{i=1}^{\infty} E[X_i]E[X]=E[∑i=1∞​Xi​]=∑i=1∞​E[Xi​] (using linearity of expectation)

E[X1]=16⋅1+...+16⋅5+16⋅5=206E[X_1] = \frac{1}{6} \cdot 1 + ... + \frac{1}{6} \cdot 5 + \frac{1}{6} \cdot 5 = \frac{20}{6}E[X1​]=61​⋅1+...+61​⋅5+61​⋅5=620​

E[X2]=P( first die roll was 6)⋅( terms that matchE[X1])E[X_2] = P(\text{ first die roll was 6} ) \cdot (\text{ terms that match} E[X_1])E[X2​]=P( first die roll was 6)⋅( terms that matchE[X1​])

  ⟹  E[X2]=16⋅206\implies E[X_2] = \dfrac{1}{6} \cdot \dfrac{20}{6}⟹E[X2​]=61​⋅620​

  ⟹  E[X3]=162⋅206\implies E[X_3] = \dfrac{1}{6^2} \cdot \dfrac{20}{6}⟹E[X3​]=621​⋅620​

This is a Geometric Progression, with a=20/6,r=1/6a = 20/6, r=1/6a=20/6,r=1/6, the sum of infinite terms will be a(1−r)=20/61−1/6=4\dfrac{a}{(1-r)} = \dfrac{20/6}{1-1/6} = 4(1−r)a​=1−1/620/6​=4

Note: This will not work for a problem that involves a state. For instance, if the monkey could cheat upto 3 times (i.e, re-throw the dice even when it is not a "6"), and the cheating-count was reset to zero when a real "6" appears, then this method will not work.
